1- Dashboard: To view and drill down
2 - Graph: Just for visualization NOT drill down
I would say Dashboard and Graph...the question states "create VISUALISATIONS for Managers"...no?
it states that "You need to create visualizations for managers", so answer should be Graph for both
I would say Graph fro both, Dashboard only is vague answer
The second question should be a "chart" as a diagram is needed
Please can someone explain why dashboard and report has been selected as answer?

comments.content: In the requirements it states "Allow managers to be able to view a diagram and drill down to leads converted in the last 30 days." You would do this with a dashboard.

discussion.content:
1.system
2.parent
Goal setting process:
You can create parent goals based on criteria like market research, budget planning, and historical performance. You'll typically assign parent goals to managers, and then assign child goals to individuals, teams, organizations, territories, and product lines. These child goals roll up into the overall goals for a specified metric.

I wonder why A cannot be the answer. They said ,” The report must contain a chart that displays the type of ticket purchaser (alumni, non-alumni, and student).” so I thought X axis should contain type of ticket purchaser.

comments.content: I assume with "Purchaser" the actual person who bought the ticket was meant

questions.question_text:
You need to create a chart for the athletic director.
What should you do?

choices.D: Use discount price on the X-axis. Use the number of tickets for groups on the Y-axis.
choices.A: Use purchaser, markup, and margin on the X-axis. Use amount of sales on the Y-axis.
choices.B: Use the ticket type as the X-axis. Use amount of sales on the Y-axis
choices.C: Use the ticket type on the X-axis. Use margins multiplied by cost on Y-axis

questions.answer_description:
Enforce repeatable steps to promote and increase efficiency and consistency for ticket sales across all sports and venues.
Reference:

questions.question_text:
You need to increase efficiency and consistency for ticket sales to meet company requirements.
What should you create?

discussion.content: Launch a playbook to carry out activities consistently https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/sales-enterprise/launch-playbook

SQL Server Reporting Services reports. These reports use SQL queries and filtered views to retrieve report data. Filtered views restrict the data to what is available to the security role of the person running the report. All the default reports included with Customer Engagement (on-premises) are SQL-based reports.

You cannot access filtered views in Dynamics 365 Customer Engagement because access to the SQL database is not supported. If you have a Dynamics 365 (online) or Power Apps subscription, use Fetch-based reports for custom reporting.

Fetch-based Reporting Services reports. These reports use FetchXML queries that are proprietary to Customer Engagement (on-premises) instead of filtered views to retrieve data for reports. Reports that you create by using the Report Wizard in are Fetch-based reports.

THE ANSWER IS CORRECT. FETCH-BASED REPORT

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/model-driven-apps/add-reporting-to-app?context=%2Fdynamics365%2Fcontext%2Fsales-context

System reports are available to all users. Individuals who create or otherwise own reports can share them with specific colleagues or teams or can make the reports available to the organization so that all users can run them. These reports use FetchXML queries that are proprietary to Microsoft Dataverse and retrieve data to build the report. Reports that you create in a Power Apps app are Fetch-based reports.

comments.content: What I grasped is if on-premise use SQL if online use Fetch-based reporting
